etymology.description: 凤梨 + 酥 = pineapple + flaky pastry → pineapple cake.
etymology.interpretation: Refers to a flaky pastry with pineapple filling, especially associated with Taiwan. Literally means “pineapple pastry,” emphasizing the fruit and the crumbly texture.
etymology.simplification: 鳳 → 凤 was simplified to reduce strokes; 梨 and 酥 are unchanged. Meaning and usage remain the same across scripts.

examples.chinese: 我买了一盒凤梨酥送朋友(我買了一盒鳳梨酥送朋友)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ mǎile yì hé fènglísū sòng péngyǒu.
examples.english: I bought a box of pineapple cakes as a gift for a friend.

examples.chinese: 台湾的凤梨酥外皮酥香、内馅酸甜(臺灣的鳳梨酥外皮酥香、內餡酸甜)。
examples.pinyin: Táiwān de fènglísū wàipí sūxiāng, nèixiàn suāntián.
examples.english: Taiwan’s pineapple cakes have a fragrant flaky crust and a sweet-tart filling.

examples.chinese: 咖啡配凤梨酥很搭(咖啡配鳳梨酥很搭)。
examples.english: Coffee pairs well with pineapple cakes.
